response:
The subacute evolution over several days of a crossed brainstem syndrome (left third nerve palsy with contralateral pyramidal and cerebellar signs) in a 58-year-old with vascular risk factors most strongly suggests an ischaemic midbrain infarct, but the concurrent optic neuropathy raises the possibility of a demyelinating or inflammatory process; neoplastic and structural vascular causes of a focal midbrain lesion must also be considered.
